context: Several caveats should be considered in interpreting the results of this study. First, as previously noted, direction of causal associations cannot be determined given the cross-sectional design. It is certainly possible that elevated neopterin levels are not due to SDB per se but due to other factors such as obesity. Indeed, studies on healthy lean and overweight subjects show that BMI and measures of central obesity (ie, waist circumference) are associated with higher neopterin levels. 56 However, despite statistical adjustments for BMI, waist circumference, and percentage of body fat, the associations between SDB severity and serum neopterin levels persisted. Second, it is also possible that, regardless of the careful selection of the patient sample and exclusion of various comorbidities, subclinical vascular disease may underlie the observed association. Finally, the modest sample size and the lack of female subjects limit the generalizability of our findings.
